Service upon a party, or an attorney representing a party, shall occur at theime of hand delivery; or, if service is done by mail, by the date of theostmark on the envelope in which the document was sent, plus three (3) businessays. An answer to a Notice of Infraction and Proposed Order, shall be served on WASA,nd any other party to the action, within thirty (30) days after the date ofervice of the Notice of Infraction and Proposed Order. A response to any motion filed in an action shall be served on all the partiesithin thirty (30) days after the date of service of the motion or otherleading. The hearing examiner may extend the thirty (30) day deadline imposed by thisection upon a showing of good cause by the party seeking the extension. Unless otherwise directed by the hearing examiner, all requests to the hearingxaminer for an order or other relief, except for the Proposed Orderccompanying WASA’s Notice of Infraction, shall be made by motion, inriting, except that motions made during a hearing may be made orally. The hearing examiner may decide a motion with or without a hearing. If a moving party fails to appear at a hearing on its motion, the hearingxaminer may treat the motion as withdrawn, and the motion may be refiled onlyith the permission of the hearing examiner, upon a showing of good cause by theoving party. If the opposing party fails to appear at the hearing, the hearing examiner mayreat the motion as conceded and grant the motion, except that the opposingarty may request that the hearing examiner vacate the order granting theotion, upon a showing of good cause by the opposing party. All parties are encouraged to engage in voluntary discovery. Discovery may bebtained by any of the following methods: Depositions upon oral examination or written questions; Written interrogatories; Requests for production of documents or other intangible things; Requests to conduct site visits; and Requests for admissions. Responses to requests for discovery shall be provided within thirty (30) daysnless the parties agree to a different deadline or the hearing examiner, uponotion by one of the parties and for good cause shown, establishes a differenteadline. If a party fails to permit or provide discovery, an aggrieved party may file aotion to compel discovery with the hearing examiner. When determining whether to admit any material or testimony into evidence, theearing examiner shall be guided by the rules of evidence applicable in civilroceedings in the D.C. Superior Court. If the hearing examiner concludes thathe admission of evidence that would not be permitted by the court would beelpful to the determination of the matter before him or her, the hearingxaminer may admit that testimony or material into evidence.
